extraction_metadata.article_title: Hypothesis-driven Adaptation of Business Models based on Product Line Engineering

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Business Model Decision Line (BMDL) - A concept that applies the engineering process of Software Product Lines (SPLs) to the structure of the Business Model Canvas (BMC) to support the process of business model adaptation by matching business domain knowledge in the form of a feature model with customer needs to derive hypotheses about the business model together with experiments for validation.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We call this concept a Business Model Decision Line (BMDL). The BMDL matches business domain knowledge in the form of a feature model with customer needs to derive hypotheses about the business model together with experiments for validation.'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: BMDL
Business Model Decision Line
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We call this concept a Business Model Decision Line (BMDL)'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'We implement our approach in a tool and illustrate the usefulness with an example of developing business models for a mobile application.' | Page 5: 'In the example, we create an adaptive business model for a to-do app in the market of mobile applications.'

extracted_data.question_text: What specific customer segment is most detailed in the article regarding the software business model?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Private users with different specializations (fitness improver, life improver, business improver)
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 6: 'we focused on different customer segments of private users for which we proposed different value propositions to solve their problems. Here, we have the fitness improver, who will get special features for meal and gym times, and life improver, who we will propose to save a work&life balance. Moreover, we have business improver, where we will use the proposition to optimize workflows to get more done at the same time.'

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Different value propositions for different customer segments (fitness features, work-life balance, workflow optimization)
Customer Segment: Private Users, Professional Users, fitness improver, life improver, business improver
Channels: Facebook advertisements, specialized online communities, Facebook groups
Revenue Streams: In-App Advertisements, License Subscription, License Purchase
Key Activities: Business model adaptation, hypothesis validation through experiments
Key Resources: Feature model, business domain knowledge, experimentation artifacts
Key Partnerships: not reported
Customer Relationship: Customer support mentioned for business improver segment
Cost Structure: not reported
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2: 'The BMC divides the business model into the nine building blocks of Customer Segments, Value Propositions, Channels, Customer Relationships, Key Activities, Key Resources, Key Partners, Revenue Streams, and Cost Structure' | Page 6: 'we focused on different customer segments of private users for which we proposed different value propositions' | Page 6: 'customer support as relationship and workflow tracking as value offering for business improver'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_value: Business Developer | Creates and adapts business models | Uses BMDL approach to derive business models | Interacts with customers through experiments
Customers | Provide feedback and validation | Participate in experiments and surveys | Provide needs and requirements
Competitors | Provide market context | Analyzed for business model decisions | Not directly interacting
Domain Experts | Provide market knowledge | Consulted during market analysis | Share expertise with business developers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'The business developer needs to define the range of the scope' | Page 4: 'interviews with domain experts or the analysis of market reports can be done' | Page 5: 'analyze how their competitors solve a customer problem' | Page 6: 'customer surveys or customer journeys can be performed'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Continuous innovation requirement to stay competitive
Difficulty in defining effective business models
Need to adapt to uncertain and changing customer needs
Requirement to validate business model hypotheses efficiently and effectively
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'The continuous innovation of its business models is an important task for a company to stay competitive' | Page 1: '64% of these executives have the difficulty to define an effective business model to support new ideas and make them profitable' | Page 1: 'adapting to uncertain and changing customer needs effectively and efficiently'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Comprehensive overview of possible business model adaptations → Effective discovery of multiple configurations
Separation of business model construction from experiment conduction → Efficient reuse of experimentation artifacts
Deep analysis of market, competitors, and customers → Competitive advantage through working business model decisions
Feature model development for one product as starting point → Reusability for other products
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'The effectiveness of our approach is supported by the derivation of business models from a common superset of possible business model adaptations' | Page 7: 'The efficiency of our approach is supported by the separation of the construction of business models from conducting experiments' | Page 7: 'we discovered in our example, that it has advantages in combining working business model decisions of competitors with our own niche decisions to gain a competitive advantage'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Business domain knowledge → Required for creating feature model
Market analysis → Affects domain scoping and feature identification
Competitor analysis → Influences business model decision identification
Customer needs analysis → Determines feature selection and business model derivation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'The Domain Scoping collects the information about the target market, existing competitors, and the niche of the own product' | Page 4: 'The Domain Modeling uses this information to create a feature model' | Page 5: 'The Customer Analysis connects the knowledge of Business Analysis with the concrete needs of the customers'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Professional Users require Save Privacy option → Excludes In-App Advertisements
Facebook Ads requires Private Users as customers → Limits customer acquisition channel options
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'In our example, the In-App Advertisement is excluded from Save Privacy and the Facebook Ads requires Private User[s] as customers'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Time-consuming scoping process compared to direct business model development
Finding the right granularity for feature modeling
Some experimentation artifacts are too specific for efficient reuse
Upfront investment required for deep analysis and artifact identification
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'it is comparatively time-consuming to analyze the market and competitors instead of starting directly with the development of a business model' | Page 7: 'The Modeling Granularity is a major issue both in business modeling and traditional SPL engineering' | Page 7: 'we realized that some artifacts are too specific to reuse them one-to-one for different hypotheses'

extracted_data.question_text: What practices are used to mitigate challenges of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Starting with coarser granularity and refining when required → Mitigates modeling granularity issues → Reduces time increase in scoping process
Reactive approach to extend feature model incrementally → Mitigates upfront investment challenge → Allows adaptation to new requirements
Thinking about which artifacts are reusable and which can be evolved → Mitigates artifact specificity challenge → Speeds up business model adaptation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 7: 'we propose starting with a coarser granularity to model the main variation points of different business model decisions and refine this granularity when it is required' | Page 4: 'we adopt the idea of Alves et al. to build an extractive feature model of business model decisions that is extended in a reactively by analyzing customer needs' | Page 7: 'we see it as an advantage for business developers to think about which artifacts are reuseable and which former artifacts can be evolved for reusing'

extracted_data.question_text: What metrics and quantitative results are reported in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Metric: Business model decisions; Value: 89; Unit: decisions; Period: not specified; Method: domain model creation; Source: existing business domain model
Metric: Competitor business model decisions; Value: 47-60; Unit: decisions; Period: not specified; Method: competitor analysis; Source: Microsoft ToDo (47), Wunderlist (60), Any.do (57), Todoist (57)
Metric: Feature model features; Value: 152; Unit: features; Period: not specified; Method: feature model abstraction; Source: business model decisions analysis
Metric: Niche decisions; Value: 31; Unit: decisions; Period: not specified; Method: niche analysis; Source: competitor weakness analysis
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4: 'It was created for mobile applications and consists of 89 variation points of different business model decisions' | Page 5: 'we analyzed the to-do apps named Microsoft ToDo (which consists of 47 business model decisions), Wunderlist (60 decisions), Any.do (57 decisions) and Todoist (57 decisions)' | Page 5: 'we used the business model decisions to abstract a feature model with 152 features' | Page 5: 'we found different niches (31 decisions), which are currently not implemented by the analyzed competitors'

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Microsoft ToDo → Analyzed as competitor with 47 business model decisions
Wunderlist → Analyzed as competitor with 60 business model decisions
Any.do → Analyzed as competitor with 57 business model decisions
Todoist → Analyzed as competitor with 57 business model decisions
Apple's iOS → On-board applications with 27 business model decisions
Google's Android → On-board applications with 26 business model decisions
BMDL Feature Modeler → Tool implementation of the BMDL approach
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 5: 'we analyzed the to-do apps named Microsoft ToDo (which consists of 47 business model decisions), Wunderlist (60 decisions), Any.do (57 decisions) and Todoist (57 decisions), together with the on-board applications of Apple's iOS (27 decisions) and Google's Android (26 decisions)' | Page 6: 'We implemented our solution in a web-based tool called BMDL Feature Modeler'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Standard Subscription → Basic subscription tier
Premium Subscription → Advanced subscription tier
Free For All → Freemium model with in-app advertisements
License Subscription → Paid subscription model
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1: 'which is Free For All (FA) by using In-App Ads (IA)' | Page 5: 'License Subscription could be refined to Standard Subscription and Premium Subscription' | Page 1: 'As a result, they add License Subscription (LS) as an additional revenue stream'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Use questionnaire models to improve derivation of business knowledge and customer needs
Integration of business model patterns in the tool to support idea generation
User study in the form of a student seminar on lean development of mobile applications
Analysis of the evolvement of the feature model and reusability of experiments over time
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 8: 'First, we want to use questionnaire models to improve the derivation of business knowledge and customer needs. Moreover, we want to integrate business model patterns in our tool to support idea generation. Second, we want to evaluate the applicability of our approach by providing a user study in the form of a student seminar on the lean development of mobile applications at the university. In the seminar, our approach should be used over time to analyze the evolvement of the feature model and the reusability of the experiments.'
